Graphical abstract Triple-shell hollow spheres of crystalline copper–nickel ferrite have been synthesized in a simple one-pot procedure using carbon spheres as templates via a hydrothermal approach. Ferric nitrate, copper nitrate, and nickel nitrate were dissolved in water together with glucose, and the mixture was heated to 180 °C in an autoclave. Finally, the carbon core was removed by calcination at 550 °C. The triple-shell hollow spheres of CuNiFe2O4 were characterized by XRD, TEM, FE-SEM, and EDS. High catalytic activity for the Suzuki reaction was obtained for this new triple-shell hollow sphere of CuNiFe2O4. This also reveals obvious advantages such as the recyclability of the catalyst, simple experimental operation, and excellent yields. Keywords Heterogeneous catalyst Suzuki–Miyaura reaction Micro/nanostructure Hollow triple-shell nanospheres CuNiFe2O4 1 Introduction The essential driving force in the critical field of heterogeneous catalysis is the design and synthesis of new catalysts, which are the basis of energy conversion [1]. Transition metal ferrites (MFe2O4, M = Ni, Cd, Zn, etc.) possessing the spinel structure have been investigated in detail due to their thermal, mechanical, and chemical stability [2] and for their structural, electrical, and magnetic properties [3,4]. Ferrites are appealing in a wide array of applications in electronics [5], ferrofluids [6], magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) [7], drug delivery systems [8], pigments [9], catalysts [10], and sensors [11]. In particular, ferrites have been used effectively in catalysis [12,13] and photocatalysis [14] for a number of organic reactions, such as CC and CX coupling [12], alkylation [15], and oxidation of some species such as alcohols [16], CO [17], styrene [18,19], and toluene [20,21]. The most commonly explored synthesis procedures for these spinel ferrite nanoparticles are sol–gel [22], radiofrequency plasma treatment [23], reverse micelles [24], host templates [25], co-precipitation [26], hydrothermal treatment [27], and polyol-assisted synthesis [28]. Hollow nanostructures, as a class of materials with a particular morphology, have attracted attention in the past decades due to their special physical and chemical properties, which are different from those of conventional solid nanoparticles [29]. These special properties of hollow nanostructures are owing to their well-defined morphology, uniform size, low density, larger specific surface area, and wide range of potential applications [30–35]. Recently, the preparation of hollow spheres with multiple shells has been attracting attention because of their better performance and their widespread applications in drug delivery, heterogeneous catalysis, sensors, lithium ion batteries, photocatalysis [36–40], and environmental engineering [41–44]. Similarly to single-shell or double-shell micro/nanostructured materials, there are three distinct methods for generating multishell hollow structures with controllable shapes: hard templating, soft templating, and template-free methods [44–46]. CC bond formation reaction is one of the most useful methods for production of biaryl compounds, which constitute a wide range of natural products and pharmaceuticals [47a]. A large number of protocols have been developed for the Suzuki reaction with the use of iron [48,49], manganese [50], cobalt [51,52], ruthenium [53], copper [54,55], gold [56], nickel [57], rhodium [58], palladium [59], and other complexes [60–62] as catalysts. However, these methods have several major drawbacks: expensive reagents, difficulty in workup, environmental hazards, and difficulty in recycling the catalyst. Therefore, design and synthesis of new heterogeneous catalysts with easy separation and recyclability for CC cross-coupling reactions have been the subject of much interest [47]. There are few reports of synthesis of hollow spheres of ternary transition metal ferrites, because formation of a uniform coating of ternary ferrites on the surface of a template is difficult [63]. To the best of our knowledge, hollow nanospheres of CuNiFe2O4 as a mixed ternary transition metal ferrite have not been introduced yet as a candidate for catalyzing the Suzuki reaction. Therefore, it could be profitable to investigate the performance of hollow spheres of copper nickel ferrite in the catalysis of the Suzuki reaction, as an important organic reaction. Here, following our previous work [64], we report a facile one-step hydrothermal method for the synthesis of hollow nanostructured copper nickel ferrite using ferric nitrate, copper nitrate, and nickel nitrate as the reactants and glucose as a chelating agent. In addition, the catalysis performance in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction has been studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 General procedure for preparation of triple-shell hollow spheres Certain amounts of 1 M glucose solution, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O solution (1 M, 2 eq.), Cu(NO3)2·6H2O solution (1 M, 0.5 eq.), and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O solution (1 M, 0.5 eq.) were dispersed in 10 mL distilled water. After being stirred for about 30 min, the mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was maintained at 180 °C for 24 h and then naturally cooled to ambient temperature. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water and ethanol, and dried at 100 °C. Finally, the hollow spheres were obtained after calcination at 550 °C for 3 h. 2.2 General procedure for the cross coupling of arylboronic acids with aryl halides The quantities 1.2 mmol of phenylboronic acid, 1.0 mmol of aryl halides, 2 mmol K2CO3, and 0.01 g CuNiFe2O4 hollow spheres as catalysts were added to 5 mL ethanol/water (3:1) under stirring for an appropriate time at 80 °C. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated by an external magnet and the product was extracted with ethyl acetate and purified by column chromatography. The recovered catalyst was washed with ethanol and dried at 80 °C for further use. 2.2.1 Biphenyl (1) White solid; m.p. 70–71 °C; 1H NMR (CDCl3, 300 MHz): δ = 7.37–7.40 (m, 2H), 7.43–7.53 (m, 4H), 7.63–7.68 (m, 4H); m.p. 122–123 °C; 1H NMR (CDCl3, 300 MHz): δ = 2.66 (s, 3H), 7.41–7.53 (m, 3H), 7.64–7.67 (m, 2H), 7.71 (d, 2H, J = 8.4 Hz), 8.06 (d, 2H, J = 8.4 Hz); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 75 MHz): δ = 26.71, 127.24, 127.30, 128.28, 128.96, 129.00, 135.86, 139.86, 145.77, 197.77. 3 Results and discussion A brief procedure for synthesis of triple-shell hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres with carbon spheres as templates is depicted in Scheme 1 . At the first step, metal precursors were fabricated in situ on the surfaces of carbon spheres from a mixed solution of glucose, Fe3+, Ni2+, and Cu2+ by a hydrothermal method. The carbon core was eliminated by calcination and the expected hollow spheres were obtained. The nanocatalyst was characterized by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The uniform carbon spheres are fabricated by a facile and environmentally friendly route. This simplified pathway for the formation of carbon spheres involves the dehydration of carbohydrate followed by a carbonization process [65]. The carbon spheres were prepared from glucose/water solutions under hydrothermal conditions at 180 °C without use of any additives. Fig. 1 a shows the FE-SEM image of the smoothed surface carbon spheres with diameters around 1 µm and with spherical morphology. The surfaces of the produced carbon spheres are hydrophilic and are functionalized with OH and CO groups, which are formed from non- or partially dehydrated carbohydrates. This provides the available reactive sites with a high capacity for metal ion adsorption [65]. By heating a mixture of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (1 M), Cu(NO3)2·6H2O (1 M), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1 M) and glucose (1 M) at 180 °C for about 24 h in an autoclave, an increase in the size of synthesized carbon spheres was achieved. This could be interpreted by the fact that during the hydrothermal treatment, metal ions are accumulated near the hydrophilic shell [66]. Fig. 1b displays a considerable increase in the diameter of the carbon spheres (from approximately 1 to 2 µm in diameter). Subsequently, the carbon sphere template was removed by thermal decomposition during calcination at 550 °C for 3 h in ambient atmosphere. The resultant product exhibited triple shells of hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres. Hollow spheres were obtained after calcination and were studied by FE-SEM. Fig. 2 a is a low-magnification FE-SEM image, which clearly exhibits the hollow spheres of CuNiFe2O4 particles with regular morphology. The magnified image shown in Fig. 2b exhibited the detailed morphology of the newly synthesized material, which suggested uniform hollow spheres with a diameter of about 500 nm. It is obvious from the images that the mean diameter of the obtained structure was much smaller than that of carbon spheres as shown in Fig. 1b. This confirms a considerable shrinkage of the structure during the calcination process and the removal of carbon. In addition, the hollow nature of CuNiFe2O4 could be clearly seen from this image (Fig. 2b). In addition to elemental analysis of nanoparticles, the energy-dispersive X-ray (EDS) spectrum of the triple shell-hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres was investigated. The EDS spectrum demonstrates the presence of Cu, Ni, and Fe in the matrix (Fig. 2c). To further confirm the morphology of synthesized nanoparticles, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used. The TEM image of the spheres clearly shows contrast between the pale intervals and dark edges, which confirmed the hollow interior structure (see Fig. 3 ). The thickness of the two inner sphere shells is about 25 nm and an outer shell is about 50 nm in diameter. The crystalline structure of the triple-shell hollow spheres was also studied by XRD characterization. Fig. 4 a shows a broad peak that could be referred to the amorphous nature of the carbon spheres. The diffraction patterns of the sample before and after calcination are shown in Fig. 4b and c, respectively. Clearly, no characteristic peaks of the structure of the shell were observed in the XRD pattern before calcination (Fig. 4b). The appearance of the characteristic peaks after calcination at 18.36/(1 1 1), 30.12/(2 2 0), 35.56/(3 1 1), 37.67/(2 2 2), 42.28/(4 0 0), 53.52/(4 2 2), 57.2/(4 4 0), and 62.84/(5 1 1) (Fig. 4c) are attributed to the crystalline structure of CuNiFe2O4 [67]. The XRD pattern of triple-shell hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres (Fig. 4c) was compared with that of CuFe2O4 (Fig. 4d) (JCPDS No. 77-0010) and NiFe2O4 (Fig. 4e) (JCPDS file No. 10-325). It is evident that the reflections of CuNiFe2O4 are in excellent accordance with CuFe2O4 and NiFe2O4 patterns. It is noteworthy that the broad peaks allocated to amorphous carbon are not found in the final products (Fig. 4c), implying that the carbon core in the spheres is removed completely via calcination. No peak from the impurity phase can be detected in the XRD pattern. The BET analysis was performed to evaluate the surface area of triple-shell hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres. The obtained BET surface area of triple-shell hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres was 75.17 m2/g. This obtained value is higher than the reported BET values for some multishell hollow spheres in other literature [68]. The catalytic performance of the synthesized triple-shell hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres for organic reactions was studied by applying the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction. To find the optimum conditions for this reaction, the model reaction of iodobenzene and phenylboronic acid was investigated in diverse solvents (Table 1 , entries 1–6). Low yields of the product were observed using CH3CN (Table 1, entry 4) and PEG (Table 1, entry 5), whereas EtOH, H2O, and DMF led to the corresponding biphenyl product in 81, 76, and 78% yield, respectively (Table 1, entries 1–3). EtOH/H2O was selected as the best solvent for the model reaction (Table 1, entry 6). Nevertheless, we examined several different bases for the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction catalyzed by CuNiFe2O4 hollow spheres in EtOH/H2O. The results showed that modest yields of product were observed with KOH and K3PO4 (Table 1, entries 8, 9). Higher yields were obtained for K2CO3 and Cs2CO3 among the different bases. Because of availability and price, K2CO3 was chosen as the optimum base for this reaction (Table 1, entries 6, 7). In further investigations, to optimize the conditions, several types of catalyst for the desired transformations were studied (see Table 2 ). Performing the reaction in the presence of 0.01 g of CuNiFe2O4 led to the corresponding product in 95% yield, without any side products. Other catalysts such as CuO, NiO, CuFe2O4, and NiFe2O4 gave lower conversions and Fe2O3 totally failed to produce the product. Thus, according to the results, CuNiFe2O4 was the most effective catalyst among the tested ones. The enhanced catalytic activity of CuNiFe2O4 could be attributed to the synergetic catalytic effect between the metal species. Under these optimized condition, we examined the cross-coupling reaction of phenylboronic acid with a variety of aryl halides. The results are summarized in Table 3 . The presence of electron-withdrawing groups, such as NO2, COOH, and CF3, on the aryl iodides provide the corresponding biphenyl products with excellent yields (Table 3, entries 4–6). Aryl iodides bearing electron-donating groups, such as CH3 and OCH3, reacted efficiently with phenylboronic acid with good to high yields (Table 3, entries 2, 3). These studies indicated that the simultaneous double coupling of phenylboronic acid on 2-iodo-5-bromopyridine and 1-iodo-4-bromobenzene gave triaryl compounds in high yields (Table 3, entries 7, 8). These results encouraged the authors to study the reaction of phenylboronic acid with a variety of aryl bromides. The cross-coupling reaction of aryl bromides containing electron-withdrawing or electron-donating substituents with phenylboronic acid were also readily converted in high yields to the desired biphenyl products (Table 3, entries 9–12). The whole result showed that the cross-coupling phenylboronic acid with aryl iodides provided shorter reaction time than aryl bromides. The coupling reactions of substituted aryl halides and 3-nitroboronic acid also led to the creation of the desired products at high yields (Table 3, entries 13–16). In addition, CuNiFe2O4 hollow sphere also demonstrated activity towards aryl chlorides. Both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating aryl chlorides react with phenylboronic acids with moderate yield and longer time than aryl bromides (Table 3, entries 16–20). A hot filtration test was carried out in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction to determine whether triple-shell hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres acts as a heterogeneous catalyst. For this purpose, after 40% conversion (15 min), the catalyst was separated from the reaction solution by an external magnet and the reaction was allowed to remain without catalyst for further 3 h. No progress in the reaction was observed. It can be concluded that no leaching of metal species takes place during the reaction and that the catalysis process is purely heterogeneous in nature. From the viewpoint of sustainable chemistry, reusability is one of the most important properties of metal catalysis that should be studied. The recyclability of triple-shell hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres was investigated by consecutive Suzuki cross-coupling reactions of iodobenzene with phenylboronic acid under optimized reaction conditions. The catalyst can be separated readily from the reaction solution by an external magnet. In recycling experiments, the catalyst system was stable and reusable nine times without apparent loss of catalytic activity (Fig. 5 ), while longer times were required for the reaction to be completed in cycles 10 and 11. According to the TEM image of the applied catalyst after nine recycles, no significant change in morphology of the hollow spheres from that of the fresh catalyst was detected (Fig. 6 ). The XRD pattern of the reused CuNiFe2O4 catalyst is shown in Fig. 4f. The new characteristic diffraction peaks at 2Θ = 38.6, in addition to peaks of CuNiFe2O4, were observed during recycling, which could be referred to CuO. This indicates that the base may have some influence on the catalyst structure of CuNiFe2O4 during the reaction progress. The actual mechanism of the Suzuki reaction with triple-shell hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres is not clear at this point. Further studies dealing with the mechanism of the reaction are currently going on. According to the literature and considering the above results, a possible and concise mechanism of the Suzuki reaction of iodobenzene and phenylboric acid catalyzed by triple-shell hollow CuNiFe2O4 spheres is depicted in Scheme 2 . As shown in Scheme 2, the possible mechanism has three steps. At the beginning, oxidative addition of aryl halide to CuNiFe2O4 provides aryl Cu intermediate (I). Then this intermediate reacts with phenylboronic acid, which is activated by K2CO3, and in a transmetallation reaction, aryl Cu intermediate (II) is produced. Finally, the desired product is obtained after reductive elimination of intermediate (II). However, more studies are needed for full mechanistic interpretation and understanding. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have described a simple and facile one-step procedure for synthesizing triple-shell CuNiFe2O4 hollow spheres via a hydrothermal method. We have also demonstrated that the prepared CuNiFe2O4 with hollow structure can be used as a highly efficient catalyst for the Suzuki reaction by coupling between various aryl halides and phenylboronic acid reaction under mild conditions. This micro-/nanostructure shows unique properties such as simple separation from the reaction mixture, a large surface area, and the presence of more active sites. coredata.dc:description: Triple-shell hollow spheres of crystalline copper–nickel ferrite have been synthesized in a simple one-pot procedure using carbon spheres as templates via a hydrothermal approach. Ferric nitrate, copper nitrate, and nickel nitrate were dissolved in water together with glucose, and the mixture was heated to 180 °C in an autoclave. Finally, the carbon core was removed by calcination at 550 °C. The triple-shell hollow spheres of CuNiFe2O4 were characterized by XRD, TEM, FE-SEM, and EDS. High catalytic activity for the Suzuki reaction was obtained for this new triple-shell hollow sphere of CuNiFe2O4. This also reveals obvious advantages such as the recyclability of the catalyst, simple experimental operation, and excellent yields.
coredata.dc:title: A facile hydrothermal synthesis of novel hollow triple-shell CuNiFe2O4 nanospheres with robust catalytic performance in the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction
